start.title: Zelda II: The Adventure of Link
start.brief_description: The land of Hyrule is in chaos. As Link, you’ll be sent on a treacherous journey to return six precious Crystals to their origins in six stone statues. Only by defeating the guardians of the six palaces will you gain passage to the seventh palace, take on the ultimate challenge that awaits you, and wake the Princess Zelda from her sleeping spell. On your way, helpful villagers you encounter will offer clues and secret messages invaluable in your quest. As you guide Link through the levels of Hyrule, close-ups and overviews will enhance your video vision. Are you up to the challenge?

key_work.title: The Last Emperor costumes
key_work.brief_description: These costumes from The Last Emperor enliven the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, a sense that’s reinforced by 9,500 extras who appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.

end.title: The Favourite
end.creator_credit: Ceci Dempsey, Ed Guiney, Lee Magiday and Yorgos Lanthimos
end.headline_credit: Ireland, United Kingdom and United States of America, 2018

video_links.name: THE FAVOURITE | Official Trailer | FOX Searchlight

end.brief_description: England, early 18th century. The close relationship between Queen Anne and Sarah Churchill is threatened by the arrival of Sarah’s cousin, Abigail Hill, resulting in a bitter rivalry between the two cousins to be the Queen’s favourite.

constellations_primary.name: Auteurs and Yorgos Lanthimos
constellations_primary.description: Oscar-winner Sandy Powell crafted Abigail's (Emma Stone) costume in The Favourite to represent her ascension in the royal household of Queen Anne by utilising black and white.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_other.name: Creating characters with Great costumes
constellations_other.description: Emma Fryer's costume design for The Great took inspiration from both accurate finery of the period, and contemporary designs of fashion houses like Dior. The resulting costumes evolve with the characters.

constellations_other.name: Dress to impress
constellations_other.description: In The Great, Peter and Catherine’s costumes during their Dacha visit are designed to demonstrate their unity, as they negotiate with the Swedish royals. Clothes have long been a way to communicate power, particularly in politics.

constellations_other.name: Power and privilege, monarchy and make-up

constellations_other.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_other.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

links.description: Like The Last Emperor, costume colour is intrinsic to The Favourite’s themes. While crimson and orange represent the majesty and innocence of the Emperor’s childhood, the black and white costumes in The Favourite represent courtly intrigue and symbolise chess pieces.

end.title: The Crown
end.creator_credit: Amy Roberts, Andy Stebbing, Martin Harrison, Michael Casey and Oona O'Beirn
end.brief_description: The gripping, decades-spanning inside story of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and the Prime Ministers who shaped Britain’s post-war destiny.

constellations_other.name: Bob Connolly
constellations_other.description: Australian audiences just can't seem to get enough of exploring local governments, bureaucracy and politics, whether that's through documentaries or biting social satire.

constellations_other.name: Royalty, royalty, royalty
constellations_other.description: Fascination with the royal family has persisted over the years, as seen through newsreels, documentaries, films, TV shows, tabloid news and satire.

constellations_other.name: Royals
constellations_other.description: Royal watchers don't need to visit palaces around the world. There are enough stories about royalty on the silver and small screen to get their fix.

links.description: While Olivia Coleman won an Oscar for her portrayal of Queen Anne in The Favourite, her next royal role would be as Queen Elizabeth II in season three and four of Netflix’s The Crown.

links.description: Make-up artist Ivana Primorac helped actor John Lithgow transform into British Prime Minister Winston Churchill in The Crown. She also transformed Gary Oldman into Churchill in Darkest Hour and won a Best Make-up BAFTA for her effort.

video_links.name: CRUEL INTENTIONS - Official Trailer - Back in Theaters for the 20th Anniversary

end.brief_description: Slaking a thirst for dangerous games, Kathryn challenges her stepbrother, Sebastian, to deflower their headmaster’s daughter before the summer ends. If he succeeds, the prize is the chance to bed Kathryn. But if he loses, Kathryn will claim his most prized possession.

constellations_other.name: Quiet luxury, loud transformations
constellations_other.description: In The Dressmaker, Gertrude (Sarah Snook) transforms from 'dowdy' to elegant when she attends a dance in this dress. It's a popular cinema trope that shows how characters develop, but the 'makeover' trope isn't always a positive.

constellations_other.name: Power and privilege, monarchy and make-up

links.description: The seductive tale of backstabbing set among high society was transported from pre-Revolution Paris to Manhattan in 1999 American teen movie update, Cruel Intentions. Actor Swoosie Kurtz also appears in both films.

end.title: Riverdale
end.creator_credit: Rebekka Sorensen, Amy Myrold, Arabella Anderson, Brian E. Paterson, Janine Salinas Schoenberg, Jennifer Lence, Scott Graham, Archie Comics, CBS Studios and Dustin Farrell
end.brief_description: Set in the present, the series offers a bold, subversive take on Archie, Betty, Veronica and their friends, exploring the surreality of small-town life, the darkness and weirdness bubbling beneath Riverdale’s wholesome facade.

links.description: Cruel Intentions is considered an R-rated (in America) b-grade or cult masterpiece depending on who you ask, but its influence is undeniable. The dark drama portrayed teens as being amoral, predatory and sexual, qualities that modern shows like Riverdale explore.

end.title: Dangerous Liaisons
end.creator_credit: Gladys de Segonzac and Robert Guisgand
end.brief_description: Juliette Merteuil and Valmont is a sophisticated couple, always looking for fun and excitement. Both have sexual affairs with others and share their experiences with one another. But there is one rule: never fall in love. But this time Valmont falls madly in love with a girl he meets at a ski resort, Marianne.

links.description: Though the Stephen Frears’s Oscar-winning 1988 version of Dangerous Liaisons is the most famous, the first adaptation of Choderlos de Laclos’ novel is Roger Vadim’s French version from 1959, starring Jeanne Moreau and Gérard Philipe.

results.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics
results.description: This Constellation explores how craft help actors undergo award-winning transformations into iconic characters.

key_work.title: Prosthetic Transformations
key_work.brief_description: Odd Studio turn a young woman into a witch through prosthetics and makeup, in process that involves sketching, sculpting, blasting, plastering and painting a variety of materials like silicone, alginate and clay into replicas and moulds that transform actors.

constellations_primary.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation explores how craft help actors undergo award-winning transformations into iconic characters.

start.title: The Dark Knight
start.creator_credit: Charles Roven, Christopher Nolan, Emma Thomas, Lorne Orleans and Isobel Griffiths
start.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2008
start.brief_description: From the opening sequence to the final frame, Christopher Nolan’s The Dark Knight never wastes a moment. Featuring Heath Ledger’s legendary, Oscar-winning performance as the Joker, action-packed set pieces and philosophical musings not seen in superhero movies, The Dark Knight is one of the best.

constellations_other.name: Big screen dreams
constellations_other.description: With groundbreaking technology and a unique cinema experience, today IMAX theatres are not only loved by audiences but championed by pioneering filmmakers like Christopher Nolan and James Cameron. Yet the route to get there was an unconventional one.

constellations_other.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics

end.title: The Hours
end.creator_credit: Ian MacNeil, Mark Huffam, Robert Fox and Scott Rudin
end.brief_description: “The Hours” is the story of three women searching for more potent, meaningful lives. Each is alive at a different time and place, all are linked by their yearnings and their fears. Their stories intertwine, and finally come together in a surprising, transcendent moment of shared recognition.

constellations_other.name: My People
constellations_other.description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets, 'My People' was one of the biggest hits of 2007 and propelled by the engaging music video.

constellations_other.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how craft help actors undergo award-winning transformations into iconic characters.

links.description: Fellow Australian actor Nicole Kidman also won an Academy Award for a performance highly assisted by prosthetics – she was virtually unrecognisable as Virgina Woolf in The Hours.

end.title: Moulin Rouge!
end.creator_credit: Baz Luhrmann, Catherine Knapman, Catherine Martin, Fred Baron, Martin Brown, Philip Martin Brown and Steve E. Andrews
end.headline_credit: Australia and United States of America, 2001
end.brief_description: A celebration of love and creative inspiration takes place in the infamous, gaudy and glamorous Parisian nightclub, at the cusp of the 20th century. A young poet, who is plunged into the heady world of Moulin Rouge, begins a passionate affair with the club’s most notorious and beautiful star.

constellations_other.name: Raising the Roof: on-screen levity on rooftop
constellations_other.description: Performances soar to new heights on the rooftop, not only showcasing skylines but also creating electrifying drama, comedy and spectacle.

constellations_other.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how craft help actors undergo award-winning transformations into iconic characters.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Diamonds are still a girl's best friend
constellations_other.description: This constellation explores the continuing cultural impact of Marylin Monroe’s iconic performance of 'Diamonds are a Girl’s Best Friend' in Gentlemen prefer Blondes (1953).

links.description: While Heath Ledger and Nicole Kidman took home Oscars for transformative performances, Catherine Martin has won more Oscars than any Australian for transforming actors through threads and sets. Her first two wins for Costume and Production design were for Moulin Rouge!

A young poet, who is plunged into the heady world of Moulin Rouge, begins a passionate affair with the club’s most notorious and beautiful star.

constellations_other.name: Raising the Roof: on-screen levity on rooftop
constellations_other.description: Performances soar to new heights on the rooftop, not only showcasing skylines but also creating electrifying drama, comedy and spectacle.

constellations_other.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how craft help actors undergo award-winning transformations into iconic characters.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Diamonds are still a girl's best friend
constellations_other.description: This constellation explores the continuing cultural impact of Marylin Monroe’s iconic performance of 'Diamonds are a Girl’s Best Friend' in Gentlemen prefer Blondes (1953).

end.title: Some Like It Hot
end.creator_credit: Orry-Kelly, Billy Wilder, Doane Harrison, United Artists and Michael Logan
end.brief_description: Two musicians witness a mob hit and struggle to find a way out of the city before they are found by the gangsters. Their only opportunity is to join an all-girl band as they leave on a tour.

constellations_primary.name: Some like it hot
constellations_primary.description: Australian costume designer Orry-Kelly had an eye for designing exceptional garments that worked for non-traditional Hollywood figures. His talent was highlighted when creating the gender non-conforming costumes for characters Joe / Josephine (Tony Curtis) and Jerry / Daphne (Jack Lemmon).

constellations_other.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how craft help actors undergo award-winning transformations into iconic characters.

links.description: When Martin won her second pair of Oscars for The Great Gatsby, she overtook fellow Australian costume designer Orry-Kelly, who had won three between 1952–60, including one for the Billy Wilder’s classic Some Like it Hot.

start.title: The Hours
start.creator_credit: Ian MacNeil, Mark Huffam, Robert Fox and Scott Rudin
start.brief_description: “The Hours” is the story of three women searching for more potent, meaningful lives. Each is alive at a different time and place, all are linked by their yearnings and their fears. Their stories intertwine, and finally come together in a surprising, transcendent moment of shared recognition.

constellations_other.name: My People
constellations_other.description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets, 'My People' was one of the biggest hits of 2007 and propelled by the engaging music video.

constellations_other.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how craft help actors undergo award-winning transformations into iconic characters.

end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 1990
end.brief_description: A young boy named Luke and his grandmother go on vacation only to discover their hotel is hosting an international witch convention, where the Grand High Witch is unveiling her master plan to turn all children into mice. Will Luke fall victim to the witches’ plot before he can stop them?

links.description: Kidman wore a prosthetic nose while playing Virginia Woolf but it definitely wasn’t as terrifying as the one fellow Oscar-winner Angelica Huston donned in Nicolas Roeg’s adaptation of Roald Dahl’s The Witches.

Edie Kurzer, Australia, 2020

Make-up box with make-up

Courtesy Lee-Anne Donnolley
end.brief_description: In the digital age it’s sometimes easy to overlook the physical crafts of filmmaking. Make-up and prosthetics are vital to the creation of characters in film, television and theatre - bringing werewolves, Terminators and planets full of apes to life.

links.description: The Witches was one of the last films that puppeteer and filmmaker Jim Henson personally oversaw before his death and the effects were done by his company The Creature Shop. Similarly, Henson conceived of the puppet-performed sitcom Dinosaurs a year before his death.

Featuring Heath Ledger’s legendary, Oscar-winning performance as the Joker, action-packed set pieces and philosophical musings not seen in superhero movies, The Dark Knight is one of the best.

constellations_other.description: With groundbreaking technology and a unique cinema experience, today IMAX theatres are not only loved by audiences but championed by pioneering filmmakers like Christopher Nolan and James Cameron. Yet the route to get there was an unconventional one.

links.description: Like the silicone scars on the War Boys that contributed to Odd Studio’s Oscar win, the prosthetic scars Heath Ledger wore to create the Joker’s savage smile helped the actor’s Oscar-winning transformation into the Crown Prince of Crime in The Dark Knight.

start.title: Prosthetic Transformations
start.creator_credit: Odd Studio
start.brief_description: Odd Studio turn a young woman into a witch through prosthetics and makeup, in process that involves sketching, sculpting, blasting, plastering and painting a variety of materials like silicone, alginate and clay into replicas and moulds that transform actors.

results.name: The Pitch
results.description: Explore fantastical worlds and underwater seascapes.

key_work.title: The Pitch
key_work.brief_description: Films aren’t always plotted from start to finish. In animated films, teams of artists often develop scenes and stories that are then performed to show how the rhythm and visuals will fit in the completed film. This is the ‘pitch’ and it’s an integral part of storyboarding.

end.title: Ponyo
end.creator_credit: Toshio Suzuki, Lawson, Nippon Television Network Corporation and TOHO
end.brief_description: The son of a sailor, 5-year old Sosuke lives a quiet life on an oceanside cliff with his mother Lisa. One fateful day, he finds a beautiful goldfish trapped in a bottle on the beach and upon rescuing her, names her Ponyo. But she is no ordinary goldfish.

constellations_other.name: The Pitch
constellations_other.description: Explore fantastical worlds and underwater seascapes.

links.description: Storyboarding is typically a time-consuming process undertaken by a team of people. Studio Ghibli’s Hayao Miyazaki, director of Ponyo, chooses to personally draw all the storyboards for his films.

links.description: Ponyo is an adaptation of Hans Christian Anderson’s classic story The Little Mermaid, the same story served as the inspiration for the Pokémon episode ‘The Misty Mermaid’.

end.title: Abzu
end.brief_description: ABZÛ is an exploration game where you are a lone diver in a lush ocean world. The diver descends deeper and deeper into the depths, where she will encounter majestic creatures, discover ancient secrets, and search for her true purpose.

links.description: Kellerman’s fantastical underwater performances connected to the mystery of the ocean, which is also at the heart of the experiential videogame ABZU.

links.description: The underwater ballet in ‘Misty Mermaid’ was inspired by a dance form made famous by Australian movie star, Annette Kellerman, the first actor to wear a swimmable mermaid costume on film. You can see her underwater dancing in this newsreel.

end.title: Shark Tale
end.creator_credit: Allison Lyon Segan, Bill Damaschke and Janet Healy
end.brief_description: Oscar is a small fish whose big aspirations often get him into trouble. Meanwhile, Lenny is a great white shark with a surprising secret that no sea creature would guess: He’s a vegetarian. When a lie turns Oscar into an improbable hero and Lenny becomes an outcast, the two form an unlikely friendship.

constellations_other.name: The Pitch
constellations_other.description: Explore fantastical worlds and underwater seascapes.

links.description: ABZU projects a mysterious and poetic sense of the light, atmosphere and ecology of the ocean world. In contrast, DreamWorks Animation’s Shark Tale uses cartoon-like graphics to turn the creatures of the sea into comical human-like characters.

results.name: Teens, zines and 90s scenes
results.description: Exploring representations of teen life and culture.

key_work.title: Gone Home
key_work.brief_description: When Katie returns home from overseas, she finds her house deserted and her family gone. That’s just one horror trope that Gone Home uses to mislead players as Katie searches the house for her family in this walking simulator.

constellations_primary.name: Teens, zines and 90s scenes
constellations_primary.description: Exploring representations of teen life and culture.

start.title: Joanie 4 Jackie
start.brief_description: In 1995 Miranda July dropped out of college, moved to Portland, Oregon, and typed up a pamphlet that she imagined would be the start of a revolution of girls and women making movies and sharing them with each other. The pamphlet said: “A challenge and a promise: Lady, you send me your movie and I’ll send you the latest Big Miss Moviola Chainletter Tape.” The Joanie 4 Jackie project involved zines, chainletter tapes, co-star tapes and events.

constellations_other.name: Teens, zines and 90s scenes
constellations_other.description: Exploring representations of teen life and culture.

end.title: Madeline's Madeline
end.creator_credit: Elizabeth Rao and Krista Parris

video_links.name: Madeline's Madeline - Official Trailer HD - Oscilloscope Laboratories

end.brief_description: Madeline has become an integral part of a prestigious physical theater troupe. When the workshop’s ambitious director pushes the teenager to weave her rich interior world and troubled history with her mother into their collective art, the lines between performance and reality begin to blur. The resulting battle between imagination and appropriation rips out of the rehearsal space and through all three women’s lives.

constellations_other.name: Teens, zines and 90s scenes
constellations_other.description: Exploring representations of teen life and culture.

links.description: July featured in 2018’s Madeline’s Madeline, an experimental film exploring teenage actor Madeline (Helena Howard), who experiences the blurring of boundaries between real life and the characters she inhabits.

end.brief_description: The life of a 15 year-old high school student, whose angst-ridden journey through adolescence, friendship, parents, and life teaches her what it means to grow up.

constellations_other.name: Teens, zines and 90s scenes
constellations_other.description: Exploring representations of teen life and culture.

links.description: In crafting the characters of Katie and Samantha in Gone Home, the team were very influenced by the realistic portrayal of 1990s teen life in short-lived drama My So Called Life.

end.title: Romeo + Juliet
end.creator_credit: Martin Brown, Baz Luhrmann, Catherine Martin, Gabriella Martinelli, Jill Bilcock and Philip Martin Brown
end.brief_description: In director Baz Luhrmann’s contemporary take on William Shakespeare’s classic tragedy, the Montagues and Capulets have moved their ongoing feud to the sweltering suburb of Verona Beach, where Romeo and Juliet fall in love and secretly wed. Though the film is visually modern, the bard’s dialogue remains.

constellations_other.name: Shadow play
constellations_other.description: Shadow play uses light and projection to tell stories – fundamentals that would evolve into cinematography. In the Wayang tradition, gunungan open and close performances and indicate scene changes and the puppets pass across the projection screen in a similar way to a wipe transition.

constellations_other.name: Warwick Thornton
constellations_other.description: Brimming with Shakespearean undertones and pathos, Kaytetye filmmaker Warwick Thornton's debut feature Samson and Delilah is both a universal tale and one intrinsically tied to the experience of First Peoples in Central Australia.

constellations_other.name: Dance sequins

links.description: Claire Danes, fresh from her role on My So Called Life, would go on to play Juliet in Baz Lurhmann’s take on the Shakespearian teen tragedy Romeo + Juliet.

start.title: 2001: A Space Odyssey

start.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 1968
start.brief_description: Humanity finds a mysterious object buried beneath the lunar surface and sets off to find its origins with the help of HAL 9000, the world’s most advanced super computer, in Stanley Kubrick’s masterpiece, which pushed cinematic narratives and special effects.

constellations_other.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_other.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

constellations_other.name: Sounds unreal
constellations_other.description: A history of syncing sound effects, a craft known as Foley in the USA and bootstepping in the UK.

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_other.name: Kaleidoscopic colour: Chromotrope
constellations_other.description: A focus on distinctive and innovative examples of pattern, colour and movement.

constellations_other.name: Sublime light and special effects
constellations_other.description: Explore 19th-century artist John Martin’s surprising influence on science fiction and fantasy films of the 20th century, from Jason and the Argonauts to the Lord of the Rings and the Evil Dead franchises.

end.title: The Shining
end.creator_credit: Stanley Kubrick
end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 1980
end.brief_description: Jack Torrance accepts a caretaker job at the Overlook Hotel, where he, along with his wife Wendy and their son Danny, must live isolated from the rest of the world for the winter. But they aren’t prepared for the madness that lurks within.

end.title: Street Fighter II
end.brief_description:
A sequel to Street Fighter, Street Fighter II improved upon the many concepts introduced in the first game, including the use of command-based special moves and a six-button configuration, while offering players a selection of multiple playable characters, each with their own unique fighting style and special moves.

Street Fighter II is credited for starting the fighting game boom during the 1990s. Its success led to the production of several updated versions, each offering additional features and characters over previous versions, as well as many home versions. Some of the home versions of the Street Fighter II games have sold millions of copies, with the SNES port of the first Street Fighter II being Capcom’s best-selling consumer game of all-time as of 2008.

Street Fighter II follows several of the conventions and rules already established by its original 1987 predecessor. The player engages opponents in one-on-one close quarter combat in a series of best-two-out-of-three matches. The objective of each round is to deplete the opponent’s vitality before the timer runs out. If both opponents knock each other out at the same time or the timer runs out with both fighters having an equal amount of vitality left, a “double KO” or “draw game” is declared and additional rounds will be played until sudden death. In the first Street Fighter II, a match could last up to ten rounds if there was no clear winner; this was reduced to four rounds in Champion Edition and onward. If there is no clear winner by the end of the final round, then either the computer-controlled opponent will win by default in a single-player match or both fighters will lose in a 2-player match.

After every third match in the single player mode, the player will participate in a “bonus game” for additional points. The bonus games includes (in order) a car-breaking event; a barrel breaking bonus game where the barrels are dropped off from a conveyor belt above the player; and a drum-breaking bonus game where drums are flammable and piled over each other. The bonus games were removed from the arcade version of Super Street Fighter II Turbo.

Like in the original, the game’s controls uses a configuration of an eight-directional joystick and six attack buttons. The player uses the joystick to jump, crouch and move the character towards or away from the opponent, as well as to guard the character from an opponent’s attacks. There are three punch buttons and three kick buttons of differing strength and speed (Light, Medium and Heavy). The player can perform a variety of basic moves in any position, including grabbing/throwing attacks, which were not featured in the original Street Fighter. Like in the original, the player can perform special moves by inputting a combination of directional and button-based commands.

Street Fighter II differs from the original due to the selection of multiple playable characters, each with their distinct fighting styles and special moves. Additionally, the player can also “cancel” during animation by performing another move, allowing for a combination of several basic and special moves. Both of these features would be expanded upon in subsequent installments.

end.title: Pose
end.brief_description: A dance musical that explores the juxtaposition of several segments of 1980s life and society in New York: the ball culture world, the rise of the luxury Trump-era universe and the downtown social and literary scene.

constellations_other.name: Marlene Dietrich: queering gender onscreen
constellations_other.description: Marlene Dietrich is an icon of queer style – from her proud bisexuality to her scandalous decision to wear a tuxedo on the red carpet. This constellation explores androgyny, gender non-conformity and drag on screen in the century since Dietrich's performance in Morocco (1930).

constellations_other.name: Pink, Pose, punk, Pilgrim
constellations_other.description: Alice Babidge's costume design for True History of the Kelly Gang sees the iconic foursome and their accomplices in dresses, a gender-expansive stance that connects to other rebellious outlooks on the world.

links.description: The vogue battling depicted in Pose has been adopted by queer communities around the world, including FAFSWAG, a collective of queer Maori and Pasifika activists in New Zealand. Their practice crosses theatre, film, community events, and interactive digital media, such as their documentary FAFSWAGVOGUE.COM

end.title: Before Midnight

end.headline_credit: Greece and United States of America, 2013
end.brief_description: It has been nine years since we last met Jesse and Celine, the French-American couple who once met on a train in Vienna. Now, live in Paris with twin daughters, but have spent a summer in Greece on the invitation of an author colleague of Jesse’s. When the vacation is over and Jesse must send his teenage son off to the States, he begins to question his life decisions, and his relationship with Celine is at risk.

key_work.title: Special effects in Blade Runner (Hades landscape)
key_work.brief_description: Blade Runner (1982) opens on a hellish Los Angeles skyline with no horizon in sight, but it’s far less expansive than it seems. Known as the ‘Hades landscape’, it was made from models, matte paintings and used practical effects to look like a living city.

end.title: Blade Runner
end.brief_description: Blade Runner is an adventure game with an emphasis on detective work rather than on puzzles. There are very few “real” puzzles in the game, and the gameplay mainly consists of questioning suspects, gathering evidence, etc. There are also some action sequences, and throughout the game the protagonist has the ability to use his gun. The player’s decisions can (and will) influence the outcome of the story, bringing the game to one of the six possible endings.

constellations_other.name: Neo-noir
constellations_other.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

links.description: Blade Runner had two videogame tie-ins. The first, in the mid-80s, was a run-and-gun arcade game with little to do with the film. The second is a point-and-click detective game, taking place in the same world and unpacking many of the film’s themes and plot points.

end.title: Home Alone
end.creator_credit: John Hughes
end.brief_description: Eight-year-old Kevin McCallister makes the most of the situation after his family unwittingly leaves him behind when they go on Christmas vacation. But when a pair of bungling burglars set their sights on Kevin’s house, the plucky kid stands ready to defend his territory. By planting booby traps galore, adorably mischievous Kevin stands his ground as his frantic mother attempts to race home before Christmas Day.

constellations_other.name: Colour and illusion
constellations_other.description: Exploring the science of colour, light, reflection and movement.

constellations_other.name: Neo-noir
constellations_other.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

constellations_other.name: Houses that move us
constellations_other.description: Our homes are important to us. When they’re good, they’re our havens. If that home changes, or things go wrong, it can affect us very deeply. This constellation looks at the different ways directors and game devs have positioned the home onscreen - from sanctuary, to hostile enemy.

recommendations.quote: This legendary Christmas film penned by John Hughes is one of the most quotable films in history. But it's not just a screwball kid's comedy about Kevin overcoming his fears, it's equally about maternal devotion and Catherine O'Hara's Kate McAllister quest to reunite with her son.

links.description: In Detective Pikachu, Justice Smith searches his father’s empty apartment, where a television is playing a clip from Angels with Filthy Souls, a fictional gangster film created for Home Alone.

end.credit_line:
Zanny Begg

Digital video, stereo sound, variable duration

Artbank + ACMI Commission, ACMI Collection
end.material_description: Single channel digital video and software, colour and audio
end.brief_description: The Beehive explores the unsolved murder of Sydney anti-development campaigner Juanita Nielsen. The inaugural Artbank + ACMI Commission, the video installation examines themes of gentrification, corruption, sex-work, feminism and non-conformist lifestyles.

links.description: The 1997 Blade Runner game was one of the first to include a procedurally generated ending, where the outcome of the case is different each time you play it. Similarly, Zany Begg’s artwork The Beehive uses an algorithm to determine the order of scenes.
